[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], [[United States]] | death_date = | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Detroit blues]], [[rhythm and blues]], [[soul music|soul]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 1987–present | label = [[Sub Pop]] | associated_acts = | website = [http://www.thornettadavis.com/Bio/bio.html Official website] | notable_instruments = }} '''Thornetta Davis''' (born August 11, 1963) is an [[United States|American]] [[Detroit blues]] and [[rhythm and blues]] [[singing|singer]].{{cite web |url=http://music.aol.com/artist/thornetta-davis/biography |title=Thornetta Davis Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Music.aol.com |accessdate=September 20, 2011}} She has opened for [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Gladys Knight]], and [[Etta James]], and sang backing vocals on [[Bob Seger]]'s 1991 album, ''[[The Fire Inside]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.subpop.com/artists/thornetta_davis |title=Thornetta Davis |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Subpop.com |accessdate=September 20, 2011}} She also worked with [[Kid Rock]] and [[Alberta Adams]], and has released two full-length solo albums. ==Biography== Davis was born in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], [[United States]].{{cite web|author=Jason Ankeny |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/thornetta-davis-mn0000581495/biography |title=Thornetta Davis | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} After entering a local talent contest at the age of 15, Davis went on to join the group Jas which disbanded in 1983 and then she, and another former member of Jas, and two of her high school friends formed Chanteuse, a vocal group [[Cover version|covering]] old R&B [[hit record|hits]]. She was recruited as a [[backing vocalist]] by Lamonte Zodiac & the Love Signs, a local soul group based outfit, who later became the Chisel Brothers. By 1991, Davis had moved on to back up singing for Big Chief, who recorded a couple of [[album]]s for the [[Sub Pop]] [[record label|label]]. Following the group disbanding, Davis was signed to a solo [[recording contract]] with the same label, and issued an EP, ''Shout out to the Dusthuffer'' (1995), and the following year she released her first solo album ''Sunday Morning Music''. One reviewer commented "Davis' singing is just wonderful - she's got a rich, warm voice".{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/sunday-morning-music-mw0000614557/credits |title=Sunday Morning Music - Thornetta Davis | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=1996-10-15 |accessdate=2014-01-31}} A song from the album, "Cry", was used in the "[[Isabella (The Sopranos)|Isabella]]" episode of the [[HBO]] television drama, ''[[The Sopranos]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.thornettadavis.com/Bio/bio.html |title=Thornetta Davis - Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Thornettadavis.com |accessdate=September 20, 2011}} Earlier in 1992, Davis had appeared at the [[Ann Arbor Blues and Jazz Festival]], and sang on stage with [[Bonnie Riatt]] and [[Katie Webster]]. Between 1997 and 2003, Davis was a backing vocalist for [[Kid Rock]], appearing on his albums, ''[[Devil without a Cause]]'' (1998) and ''[[Kid Rock (album)|Kid Rock]]'' (2003), and she also sang on Kid Rock's single, "[[Wasting Time (Kid Rock song)|Wasting Time]]". In 2000, Davis performed backing vocals with Kid Rock when he opened the [[VH1]] ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' Fashion Awards at [[Madison Square Garden]]. Davis performed on the [[soundtrack]] for the 2001 [[film]], ''[[Osmosis Jones]]''. In addition, her voice was used on the [[television program]], ''[[Xena Warrior Princess]]''. Davis has also [[cover version|covered]] the [[List of blues standards|blues standard]], "[[I Just Want to Make Love to You]]". She guested on [[Alberta Adams]]' 2008 album, ''Detroit is My Home''.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/detroit-is-my-home-mw0001681341/credits |title=Detroit Is My Home - Alberta Adams | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year || Title || Record label |- | 1996 || ''Sunday Morning Music'' || style="text-align:center;"|[[Sub Pop]] |- | 1998 || ''Shout out to the Dusthuffer'' || style="text-align:center;"|Sub Pop |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/thornetta-davis-mn0000581495/discography |title=Thornetta Davis | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==Awards== At the [[Detroit Music Awards]], Davis was voted Outstanding Blues Artist in 2004 and 2006, and Outstanding Blues/R&B Vocalist in 2004, 2006, 2010, 2011 and 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.detroitmusicawards.com/winners.html|title=Detroit Music Awards|author= |date= |work= |publisher=Detroitmusicwards.com |accessdate=December 16, 2012}} ==See also== *[[List of Detroit blues musicians]] *[[List of artists who have worked with Sub Pop]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME = Davis, Thornetta | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Detroit blues]] singer | DATE OF BIRTH = August 11, 1963 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davis, Thornetta}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American soul singers]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:Detroit blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Detroit, Michigan]] [[Category:Sub Pop artists]]
